snippet: Readers often expect profiles to be puff pieces. So nuanced profiles can run counter to their expectations.
abstract: Margaret Sullivan The Public Editor column addresses reader criticism of paired front-page profiles on Ferguson, Mo, police officer Darren Wilson and the teenager he shot and killed, Michael Brown; argues that some readers mistook their placement as a tacit message of equality between the two men, and that others mistook the depth of coverage as an attempt to lionize them; holds that profiles are not always puff pieces.
lead_paragraph: Readers often expect profiles to be puff pieces. So nuanced profiles can run counter to their expectations.

headline.print_headline: Meant as Portraits, Seen as Hagiography
headline.main: Meant as Portraits, Seen as Hagiography
